question: How often does a full moon occur?

content.source_1: A full moon is defined astronomically when the Moon is opposite the Sun as seen from Earth (Sun–Earth–Moon alignment), i.e., at about 180 degrees of elongation.
content.source_2: The average time between successive occurrences of the same lunar phase (the synodic month) is about 29.53 days.
content.source_3: The Moon completes one revolution around Earth relative to the distant stars in about 27.32 days; this is its orbital (sidereal) period.
content.source_4: The sequence of lunar phases (new, first quarter, full, last quarter) progresses as the Moon moves through its orbit around Earth.
content.source_5: The Moon appears essentially “full” to casual observers for roughly a day on either side of the exact full-moon instant, though the exact full phase is a moment in time.
content.source_6: Wherever the Moon is above the horizon, observers across Earth see the same lunar phase at a given moment; differences in visibility arise from local daylight or weather, not from phase.
